clinical_validity.disease_label: immunodeficiency 80 with or without congenital cardiomyopathy

generif.text: Functional studies of the Xenopus homolog
Functional studies of the Drosophila homolog
human Mcm10 is temporarily recruited to the replication sites 30-60 min before they replicate and dissociates from chromatin after the activation of the prereplication complex
transcription of human MCM10 and TopBP1 is activated by transcription factors E2F1-3, but not by factors E2F4-7
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
These results argue that cells can tolerate low levels of p180 as long as Mcm10 is present to "recycle" it.
Mcm10 is required for chromatin loading of And-1.
Results show that MCM10 molecule is a ring-shaped hexamer with large central and smaller lateral channels and a system of inner chambers.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
MCM10 is essential for the efficient elongation step of chromosome replication.
These results indicate that MCM10 protein is essential for maintaining genome integrity as well as cell cycle progression.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)

DNA and p180 binding to an Mcm10 construct that contains both the ID and CTD, provide the first mechanistic insight into how Mcm10 might use a handoff mechanism to load and stabilize pol alpha within the replication fork.
MCM10 interacts directly with RECQ4 and regulates its DNA unwinding activity.
Observational study of gene-disease association. (HuGE Navigator)
Assembly of the Cdc45-Mcm2-7-GINS complex requires the Ctf4/And-1, RecQL4, and Mcm10 proteins.

High doses of ionizing gamma radiation and exposure to a combination of DNA-damaging chemicals do not decrease Mcm10 protein levels, demonstrating that Mcm10 down-regulation is triggered only by UV-specific damage
Clinical trial of gene-disease association and gene-environment interaction. (HuGE Navigator)

Mcm10 utilizes a modular architecture to act as a replisome scaffold, which helps to define possible roles in origin DNA melting, Pol alpha recruitment and coordination of enzymatic activities during elongation.
This report shows that human Mcm10 is an acetylated protein regulated by SIRT1, which binds and deacetylates Mcm10 both in vivo and in vitro, and modulates Mcm10 stability and ability to bind DNA.

Data suggest that CDC45 and MCM10 (minichromosome maintenance complex component 10) directly interact and establish a mutual co-operation in DNA binding; key domains appear to interact and then interact with DNA inside cells or in cell-free systems.
Loss of Mcm10 engages checkpoint, DNA repair and SUMO-dependent rescue pathways that collectively counteract replication stress and chromosome breakage. [Review]

RecQL4-dependent association of Mcm10 and Ctf4 with replication origins appears to be the first important step controlled by S phase promoting kinases and checkpoint pathways for the initiation of DNA replication in human cells.
MCM10 is the natural substrate of the Cul4-DDB1[VprBP] E3 ubiquitin ligase whose degradation is regulated by VprBP, but Vpr enhances the proteasomal degradation of MCM10 by interacting with VprBP.

Results show that MCM10 is significantly upregulated in urothelial carcinoma (UC), and associated with tumor aggressiveness. Its knockdown significantly suppressed cell proliferation in UC cell lines.

Data suggest that interaction of Mcm10 with Mcm2-7 multimer requires Mcm10 domain that contains amino acids 530-655, which overlaps with domain required for stable retention of Mcm10 on chromatin; Mcm10 conserved domain (amino acids 200-482) is essential for DNA replication; both conserved domain and Mcm2-7-binding domain are required for full activity of Mcm10.

MCM10 was significantly upregulated in prostate cancer (PCa). We found increased MCM10 expression was significantly associated with advanced clinical stage and high Gleason score PCa.  higher MCM10 expression was associated with a poorer patient prognosis in PCa. Furthermore, loss of function assays showed that MCM10 knockdown inhibited cell proliferation and colony formation, but promoted cell apoptosis.

decreased expression of beta-catenin and cyclin Dl was detected in MCM10 short hairpin RNA cells, implying that MCM10 might induce breast cancer metastasis via the Wnt/beta-catenin pathway.MCM10 can be defined as a potential diagnostic tool and a promising target for breast carcinoma.
High MCM10 expression is associated with lung adenocarcinoma.

MCM10 is highly expressed in lung cancer (LC) clinical specimens and significantly associated with recurrence, pathological stage and worse overall survival. MCM10 knockdown in A549 and H661 cell lines significantly suppressed cell viability, clone formation and induced G1 phase arrest by regulating the expression of CCND1. Results indicated a combined effect of MCM10CCND1 in predicting the prognosis of LC patients.
Knockdown of MCM10 Gene Impairs Glioblastoma Cell Proliferation, Migration and Invasion and the Implications for the Regulation of Tumorigenesis.
MCM10 compensates for Myc-induced DNA replication stress in breast cancer stem-like cells.
Bi-allelic MCM10 variants associated with immune dysfunction and cardiomyopathy cause telomere shortening.
Aberrant MCM10 SUMOylation induces genomic instability mediated by a genetic variant associated with survival of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.
Prognostic significance and function of MCM10 in human hepatocellular carcinoma.
BRCA2 associates with MCM10 to suppress PRIMPOL-mediated repriming and single-stranded gap formation after DNA damage.
Comprehensive analysis of DNA replication timing across 184 cell lines suggests a role for MCM10 in replication timing regulation.
Over-Activation of Minichromosome Maintenance Protein 10 Promotes Genomic Instability in Early Stages of Breast Cancer.
MCM10, a potential diagnostic, immunological, and prognostic biomarker in pan-cancer.
A critical threshold of MCM10 is required to maintain genome stability during differentiation of induced pluripotent stem cells into natural killer cells.

name: minichromosome maintenance 10 replication initiation factor

reactome.name: Activation of ATR in response to replication stress
Mitotic G1 phase and G1/S transition

summary: The protein encoded by this gene is one of the highly conserved mini-chromosome maintenance proteins (MCM) that are involved in the initiation of eukaryotic genome replication. The hexameric protein complex formed by MCM proteins is a key component of the pre-replication complex (pre-RC) and it may be involved in the formation of replication forks and in the recruitment of other DNA replication related proteins. This protein can interact with MCM2 and MCM6, as well as with the origin recognition protein ORC2. It is regulated by proteolysis and phosphorylation in a cell cycle-dependent manner. Studies of a similar protein in Xenopus suggest that the chromatin binding of this protein at the onset of DNA replication is after pre-RC assembly and before origin unwinding. Alternatively spliced transcript variants encoding distinct isoforms have been identified. [provided by RefSeq, Jul 2008].
